headline.main: Model in Anti-Obesity Ad Criticizes the Campaign

docs.abstract: Beth Anne Sacks, who appears in one of the anti-obesity ads from the city's health department, said "the ad of me doesn't scare me."

headline.main: Model in Anti-Obesity Ad Criticizes the Campaign

docs.abstract: Beth Anne Sacks, who appears in one of the anti-obesity ads from the city's health department, said "the ad of me doesn't scare me."
docs.lead_paragraph: Another of the overweight models appearing in ads from New York City's health department - one who did not have a limb edited off - criticized the campaign, saying that the ads will not have the desired effect.
docs.snippet: Beth Anne Sacks, who appears in one of the anti-obesity ads from the city's health department, said "the ad of me doesn't scare me."

headline.main: Removing a Truth, or Leg, for the Greater Good

docs.abstract: The Day: The city's justification for manipulating a photo for a poster to raise awareness about diabetes raises its own set of questions.
docs.snippet: The Day: The city's justification for manipulating a photo for a poster to raise awareness about diabetes raises its own set of questions.

headline.main: Removing a Truth, or Leg, for the Greater Good

docs.abstract: The Day: The city's justification for manipulating a photo for a poster to raise awareness about diabetes raises its own set of questions.
docs.lead_paragraph: Many years ago, a New York journalist wrote scathingly about City Hall, but found himself criticized for having committed serious factual errors. We'll leave his name out of this because he is no longer with us. De mortuis, and all that. The point is that when the lapses became known, he shrugged them off, saying they did not undermine "the larger truth" he had conveyed.
docs.snippet: The Day: The city's justification for manipulating a photo for a poster to raise awareness about diabetes raises its own set of questions.

headline.main: Personal Health: Communities Learn the Good Life Can Be a Killer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes research finding that the sedentary comforts of suburban expansion have fostered obesity, poor health, social isolation, excessive stress and depression. Photo (M)a
docs.lead_paragraph: Developers in the last half-century called it progress when they built homes and shopping malls far from city centers throughout the country, sounding the death knell for many downtowns. But now an alarmed cadre of public health experts say these expanded metropolitan areas have had a far more serious impact on the people who live there by creating vehicle-dependent environments that foster obesity, poor health, social isolation, excessive stress and depression. As a result, these experts say, our ''built environment'' - where we live, work, play and shop - has become a leading cause of disability and death in the 21st century. Physical activity has been disappearing from the lives of young and old, and many communities are virtual ''food deserts,'' serviced only by convenience stores that stock nutrient-poor prepared foods and drinks.
